TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed ThemeableAttribute extends System.Attribute

Docs.summary: Defines the metadata attribute that Web server controls and their members use to indicate whether their rendering can be affected by themes and control skins. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Control developers use the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> attribute to decorate control types and their members, to signal which ones can and cannot be affected by themes and control skins. By default, all properties exposed by a control are themeable. However, themes are typically applied only to stylistic properties; the `Themeable(false)` attribute should be applied explicitly to all non-stylistic properties. Decorating a member with the `Themeable(false)` attribute ensures that the member is not themed, regardless of the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableTheming%2A> property. For example, if the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> attribute is applied to a control and set to `false`, the control is not affected by themes even when its <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableTheming%2A> property is set to `true`.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> class maintains a static list of all types that support themes, and this list is consulted whenever the static methods <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.IsObjectThemeable%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.IsTypeThemeable%2A> are called.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how you can apply the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> attribute to a member of a control. In this example, <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> is applied to a data-bound control and `false` is passed to the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.%23ctor%2A> constructor, indicating that the `DataSourceID` member cannot have themes applied. (Passing `false` to the constructor results in a <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> instance that is equivalent to the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.No> field.)
[!code-csharp[System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute/CS/themeableattribute1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute/VB/themeableattribute1.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(bool themeable) cil managed

Docs.param: to initialize the to represent a type or member that can be affected by themes; otherwise, .
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, using the specified Boolean value to determine whether the attribute represents a type or member that is affected by themes and control skins.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Passing `true` to this constructor is equivalent to using the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.Yes> field, while passing `false` is equivalent to using the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.No> field.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how you can apply the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> attribute to a member of a control. In this example, <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> is applied to a data-bound control and `false` is passed to the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.%23ctor%2A> constructor, indicating that the `DataSourceID` member cannot have themes applied. (Passing `false` to the constructor results in a <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> instance that is equivalent to the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.No> field.)
[!code-csharp[System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute/CS/themeableattribute1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute/VB/themeableattribute1.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute Default

Docs.summary: Gets a instance that represents the application-defined default value of the attribute.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The default value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> class is equivalent to the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.Yes> field. This is not necessarily equivalent to an instance that is created using the default class constructor.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.GetHashCode%2A> method is suitable for use in hashing algorithms and data structures like a hash table.

Docs.returns: if the current instance is equivalent to a instance of the class; otherwise, .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig bool IsObjectThemeable(object instance) cil managed

Docs.param: The object to test for themes support.
Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether the object passed to the method supports themes.
Docs.returns: if the object supports themes and control skins; otherwise, .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig bool IsTypeThemeable(class System.Type type) cil managed

Docs.param: The to test for themes support.
Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether the passed to the method supports themes.
Docs.returns: if the supports themes and control skins; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> class maintains a static internal catalog of types that support themes, and this method checks the catalog to determine whether the specified <xref:System.Type> is represented there. If it is not, the method examines the <xref:System.ComponentModel.AttributeCollection> object associated with the <xref:System.Type> for the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> attribute to determine whether themes are supported.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute No

Docs.summary: Gets a instance used to decorate a type or member that is not affected by themes and control skins.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.No> field is equivalent to creating an instance using the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.%23ctor%28System.Boolean%29> constructor and passing `false`.

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current control or member of a control can be affected by themes and control skins defined for the Web application.
Docs.value: if the current type or member can be affected by themes; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks A member is affected by themes if no <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> attribute is defined explicitly for the member, or the `Themeable(true)` attribute is applied. A member is not affected by themes if the `Themeable(false)` attribute is applied; this is the default value for <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute>.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute Yes

Docs.summary: Gets a instance used to decorate a type or member that is affected by themes and control skins.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.Yes> field is equivalent to creating an instance using the <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute.%23ctor%28System.Boolean%29> constructor and passing `true`.
